subject: Fix AgentDeploy compatibility with pre-Liberty drivers
commit_message:
Fix AgentDeploy compatibility with pre-Liberty drivers

During the Liberty cycle, we split the Boot and Deploy interfaces. Care
was used in the ConductorManager to remain backwards compatible with any
out-of-tree driver that continued to implement only the DeployInterface.

However, the new AgentDeploy class began to access "task.driver.boot"
directly, leading to incompatibility with any driver that mixed the
AgentDeploy interface with a Kilo-era Power / Management interface and
failed to instantiate any BootInterface. Since such an interface didn't
exist in Kilo, it's unreasonable to think those drivers would
instantiate it.

This patch fixes this within the AgentDeploy class by detecting the
absence of an instance of the boot interface on the supplied task.driver
object, and temporarily using an instance of PXEBoot instead, without
modifying the supplied task.driver object. The PXEBoot interface is
chosen because this was and is the default behavior of the Agent
drivers; even the unit tests assert this to be true.

This split also mixes the FakeBoot class with iLO and iRMC drivers, as
those drivers *do not* expect this new behavior. Adding FakeBoot will
stop the AgentDeploy class from adding in the PXEBoot behavior, to keep
these drivers working as expected.

Unit tests are included which inherit from the existing TestAgentDeploy
test class where possible, and then unset self.driver.boot so as to
imitate the behavior of an out-of-tree driver.

Additional unit tests are added to explicitly set driver.boot to an
instance of FakeBoot and ensure that AgentDeploy continues to call it as
appropriate. This could not be done by inheriting from the existing
TestAgentDeploy class, because that class is testing for calls to the
PXEBoot interface.

Co-Authored-By: Jim Rollenhagen <jim@jimrollenhagen.com>
Closes-bug: #1502980

Change-Id: Ie0089680be1e16d965ffec0e5664e1681bb141ae

subject: Force L3 agent to resync router it could not configure
commit_message:
Force L3 agent to resync router it could not configure

If the L3 agent fails to configure a router, commit:
4957b5b43521a61873a041fe3e8989ed399903d9 changed it so
that instead of performing an expensive full sync, only that
router is reconfigured. However, it tries to reconfigure the
cached router. This is a change of behavior from the fullsync
days. The retry is more likely to succeed if the
router is retrieved from the server, instead of using
the locally cached version, in case the user or operator
fixed bad input, or if the router was retrieved in a bad
state due to a server-side race condition.

Note that this is only relevant to full syncs, as those retrieve
routers from the server and queue updates with the router object.
Incremental updates queue up updates without router objects,
so if one of those fails it would always be resynced on a
second attempt.

Related-Bug: #1494682
Change-Id: Id0565e11b3023a639589f2734488029f194e2f9d
(cherry picked from commit 822ad5f06bcef8f95f36032d4fd4709975cecc31)

subject: Support resize and cold migration
commit_message:
Support resize and cold migration

This change set adds support for cold migration and resize
to a different host.

the drivers are compatible between the source and destination host.
These methods will only be called if the driver supports shared
storage.  Currently only the SSP driver supports shared storage.

Add task flow implemention for migrate_disk_and_power_off.

There is a peculiar case when resizing a VM on the same host.
PowerVM doesn't allow two VMs to be defined with the same UUID,
therefore there is only one VM present on the host and care must
be taken during a resize revert not to delete the one and only VM
we have.  To more easily detect that case and to easily see when
a VM is being resized or migrated, we rename the source VM during
the resize/migration processes.  The renamed VM will either be

confirmed or reverted.

subject: remove unneeded in_use flag checking for multipath
commit_message:
remove unneeded in_use flag checking for multipath

In iSCSI connector, _disconnect_volume_multipath_iscsi() checks
if no other multipath device attached has the iqn and portal
as same as the detaching multipath device.
The checking code using in_use flag depends on persistent-named symbolic
links("/dev/disk/by-path/ip-*") for iSCSI devices which constitute
the detaching multipath device. However, the links are deleted in
advance of calling _disconnect_volume_multipath_iscsi().
So, the checking code wouldn't work properly and should be fixed
in proper way.

The proper way is to just check whether the discovered iSCSI targets
via sendtargets discovery associate with iSCSI block devices
("/dev/disk/by-path/ip-*") or not.
If the target doesn't associate with any iSCSI block device, the target
is never used by anyone and can be disconnected.

This patch removes the in_use flag checking in
_disconnect_volume_multipath_iscsi() and the related codes.
The other codes in _disconnect_volume_multipath_iscsi are valid.

Partial-Bug: 1487169
Change-Id: I70cf5e1990cc5baffb3ef5150b9ed673e3504d6c

subject: Fix CPU pinning for odd number of CPUs w hyperthreading
commit_message:
Fix CPU pinning for odd number of CPUs w hyperthreading

Previous logic was not handling the cases when the instance cell has an
odd number of vcpus that is larger than any sibling set on the host. The
logic would (accidentally) either reject to pin such an instance even
though there is ample free cores, or would (in case there were enough
free sibling sets on the host) spread the instance instead of pack it
onto siblings as the default policy suggests.

This patch fixes some incorrect assumptions in the code, while also
simplifying it. As an added bonus - we still attempt to expose
(via the Topology, and this time correctly) the largest possible number
of threads that we can expose to the instance.

Finally - we add some more comments to clear up the intent behind the
current packing logic with pointers how it could be tweaked to achieve
different results in the future.

Change-Id: I2c0b3b250ffb1a7483299df13b317cdb24f8141d

subject: Separate the command for replace_port to delete and add
commit_message:
Separate the command for replace_port to delete and add

When a port has been added to router namespace, trying to replace the
port by adding del-port and add-port in one command, will not bring
the new port to kernel. Even if the port is updated in ovs db and can
be found on br-int, system can't see the new port. This will break
the following actions, which will manipulate the new port by ip
commands. A mail list has been filed to discuss this issue at [1].

The problem here will break the scenario that namespace is deleted
unexpectedly, and l3-agent tries to rebuild the namespace at restart.

Separating replace_port to two commands: del-port and add-port,
matches the original logic and has been verified that it can resolve
the problem here.

[1] http://openvswitch.org/pipermail/discuss/2015-December/019667.html

subject: Expire old VMs from libvirt metrics cache
commit_message:
Expire old VMs from libvirt metrics cache

This change will prevent the libvirt metrics cache from being populated
by entries from instances that are not yet active or no longer active.
Currently, the metrics cache may have both, leading to performance
issues in cases of a high VM churn.

First, VM probation testing has been moved above metric cache
initialization for each instance.  Second, before writing the metric
cache, each instance's last update time is examined.  If the instance
hasn't seen new metrics within the VM probation period, it will be
excluded from the metrics cache.  As an added precaution, in the
event that VM probation is disabled (by setting it the time to 0, as
mentioned in the documentation), this change uses the check iteration
time as a buffer to prevent active VMs from being excluded from the
cache.

A default VM probation time has been specified, too, in case the value
is missing from the configuration file.

Change-Id: I93cc42fab83cf0b6304601582f4d52b7780fe43b

subject: Switch Agent thread count test to global threshold
commit_message:
Switch Agent thread count test to global threshold

Currently, the multi-threaded ServicesCheck class will compare the
thread number allocated to each plugin against the total number of
threads in use by the Collector.  If several ServicesCheck-based plugins
are in active use, though, a normal and reaonsable number of Collector
threads would throw an exception due to an "exploding" thread count.

This change replaces the existing apples-to-oranges thread count
comparison with one global maximum number of threads.  In the highly
unlikely event of runaway thread allocation, this would provide a level
of protection, while still allowing normal operation of a large numbe
of multithreaded plugins.

Presently the timeline directive is a single gigantic directive
containing all of the timeline code. Given the amount of code

difficult to improve.

This refactors the single timeline directive into four separate
collaborating directives: a controller, an overview, a viewport,

via the controller. This separation should greatly improve future
